repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Supporting Access to On-site
            Sanitation Services through Output-Based Aid Scheme Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Supporting Access to
            On-site Sanitation Services through Output-Based Aid Scheme
            Project for Senegal were as follows: outcome was moderately
            unsatisfactory, risk to development outcome was high, Bank
            performance was moderately unsatisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: premature cessation of donor engagement
            can lead to a loss in momentum for major sector reform.
            Benefits of water investments may not be realized without
            adequate attention to sanitation. Raising tariffs only for
            one customer group may not be effective for ensuring long
            term sustainability. Determining the right threshold of the
            beneficiary contribution is vital for the successful
            delivery of peri-urban sanitation services. Complex
            management and institutional arrangements lead to
            implementation delays.

repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Supporting Access to On-Site
            Sanitation Services through Output-Based Aid (OBA) Scheme Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Supporting Access to
            On-Site Sanitation Services through Output-Based Aid (OBA)
            Scheme Project for Senegal were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: the technological options should
            not be too firmly set at the outset. Thus, in this case,
            one-quarter of the facilities ultimately built were options
            not originally proposed: connections to existing condominium
            systems and construction of the superstructure by
            beneficiaries themselves. It should be possible for the
            payment percentages going to various stakeholders (main
            contractor, social engineering, construction companies,
            etc.) to evolve during project implementation. The principle
            of full payment of the beneficiary's contribution
            before work can begin appears too rigid and does not
            encourage participation by the most underprivileged
            populations. Ways to spread out the contributions should be
            examined when future projects are implemented. This could be
            done either (i) through the project, with well defined
            requirements to be met, or (ii) by relying on microcredit
            organizations, with membership arrangements and repayment
            rates that do not excessively increase the size of the
            household contribution. The method of calculating the
            subsidy per facility should be absolutely explicit because
            this is an important indicator for monitoring the project.
            In this project, the project appraisal document, or PAD did
            not specify whether the subsidy ceiling was supposed to
            apply to each individual facility or rather, as an average
            figure, to all the facilities as a whole. This point should
            be spelled out clearly in upcoming projects.

repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Supporting Access to on-site
            Sanitation Services through OBA Scheme Project :
            environmental report

abstracts.cdata!:
This project, Supporting Access to
            on-site Sanitation Services through OBA, has as its
            principal objective the aim of reducing poverty and
            attaining millennium goals in matters of sanitation and
            potable water. It is hoped that this project will allow more
            areas, including the periurban areas, to have ready access
            to sanitation. While the project is seen as having
            tremendous upside for the community, there are several
            potential negative impacts resulting primarily from the
            construction phase. The laying of the sewer mains may result
            in damage to trees and vegetation, and as a result, there is
            a risk of soil erosion. Noise pollution will be a problem,
            as well as the possibility of accidents occurring during
            excavation. Hygiene and public health are expected to suffer
            during the period of construction. There are risks of
            flooding and overflowing in the excavated areas.

Senegal - Supporting Access to on-site
            Sanitation Services through OBA Scheme Project :
            environmental report
